prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sources near G330
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: In This science goal, we propose to observe 6 massive star forming regions in both ionised (H29a) and molecular (SO2, CS, and CH3CN) tracers to understand how the gas is moving in and around the HII region. Using a spatial resolution of 0.4”, and a spectral resolution of 0.3 km/s, we will spatially and spectrally resolve the lines described above. The largest size scales we expect for the molecules to be emitting on is ~15”. Through analysis of the line kinematics we will build up a picture of how the HII region is expanding into its environment. This places important constraints on the parameter space that theorists should be investigating as they explore how the HII regions dissipate the natal core of the protostar.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: Our Sensitivity limit is based on achieving a reasonable SNR in the continuum for all sources (and the same sensitivity across the sample), including the faintest, of our sources, G332.76 which, from LABOCA, has a peak flux of 1.14 Jy/beam in an 18.6” beam. This translates to 0.12 mJy/beam in a 0.4” beam assuming the LABOCA flux is evenly distributed through the APEX beam (which is unlikely, but gives a lower limit to the ALMA flux).
Despite how chemically active massive star forming regions can be, we expect, from our > 12000 channels to be able to combine 1000 channels to form the continuum image. To achieve a SNR of at least 4 on the continuum of our dimmest source (G332.76), we need an rms limit of 0.03 mJy/beam in the continuum. To resolve the kinematics of the proposed lines, we require a spectral resolution of ~ 0.3 km/s (244 kHz). In each channel we will achieve an rms noise of 8.5 mJy/beam (1 K). this should be high enough to observe the ionised and molecular lines in our setup.
Source Flux: The LABOCA fluxes of our sources are listed in Table 1 in the Science Justification. They range from 0.12 to 0.34 mJy/Beam in our 0.4” beam (based on the LABOCA measurements in the 8.6” beam, and assuming the LABOCA beam is uniformly filled).
Line Flux: 13CS was observed towards our dimmest source G332.76 as part of the MALT90 survey (Foster et al. 2013). The peak brightness of the 13CS line was 0.3K, which, when scaling to our resolution, our higher energy transition, and higher abundance isotopologue (12CS), should correspond to 1.68 Jy/beam. This will be easily detected at the sensitivity required to detect the continuum.
Spatial resolution: We require at least two beams across each of the HII regions we are proposing to observe with ALMA. Previous 5GHz observations of these sources show that the HII regions themselves all have radii of at least 0.6” (the smallest being G337.63-00.08), and we will have two beams across it.
Spectral resolution: in order to quantify the dynamics of lines that are a few km/s wide, we require a spectral resolution of approximately 0.3 km/s, which is achievable using a resolution of 244 kHz.
Correlator setup: To understand the dynamics of the ionised gas, we require a radio recombination line (H29a). Key molecular species that can be observed simultaneously are SO_2 and CS. Additionally, to accurately determine the temperature of the warm molecular gas (key for determining the excitation of the molecular gas), we will observe an entire K-ladder of CH3CN. This requires a larger bandwidth than possible with a single Baseband, and so we have taken half of the channels from the other baseband in the same sideband to observe the rest of the K-ladder.
Imaging: With 8 min on source, our uv coverage will be sufficient for imaging.
There are no extraordinary constraints on the calibration, bandpass accuracy or for scheduling. We do however, have an above average data rate.
This high data rate is required because of the spectral lines we need to observe to obtain our scientific result. We require (more than) an entire baseband to observe the full K-ladder of CH3CN. With CS we trace the dynamics of the dense gas, and with SO2, we trace the warm gas. With two SO2 transitions (with very different energy levels) we can constrain the excitation of the warm gas as an independent check on the temperature estimate from the CH3CN. The H29a is required to understand the dynamics of the ionised gas, and thus key to our science.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sources near G305
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: In This science goal, we propose to observe 3 massive star forming regions in both ionised (H29a) and molecular (SO2, CS, and CH3CN) tracers to understand how the gas is moving in and around the HII region. Using a spatial resolution of 0.4”, and a spectral resolution of 0.3 km/s, we will spatially and spectrally resolve the lines described above. The largest size scales we expect for the molecules to be emitting on is ~15”. Through analysis of the line kinematics we will build up a picture of how the HII region is expanding into its environment. This places important constraints on the parameter space that theorists should be investigating as they explore how the HII regions dissipate the natal core of the protostar.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: Our Sensitivity limit is based on achieving a reasonable SNR in the continuum for all sources (and the same sensitivity across the sample), including the faintest, of our sources, G332.76 which, from LABOCA, has a peak flux of 1.14 Jy/beam in an 18.6” beam. This translates to 0.12 mJy/beam in a 0.4” beam assuming the LABOCA flux is evenly distributed through the APEX beam (which is unlikely, but gives a lower limit to the ALMA flux).
Despite how chemically active massive star forming regions can be, we expect, from our > 12000 channels to be able to combine 1000 channels to form the continuum image. To achieve a SNR of at least 4 on the continuum of our dimmest source (G332.76), we need an rms limit of 0.03 mJy/beam in the continuum. To resolve the kinematics of the proposed lines, we require a spectral resolution of ~ 0.3 km/s (244 kHz). In each channel we will achieve an rms noise of 8.5 mJy/beam (1 K). this should be high enough to observe the ionised and molecular lines in our setup.
Source Flux: The LABOCA fluxes of our sources are listed in Table 1 in the Science Justification. They range from 0.12 to 0.34 mJy/Beam in our 0.4” beam (based on the LABOCA measurements in the 8.6” beam, and assuming the LABOCA beam is uniformly filled).
Line Flux: 13CS was observed towards our dimmest source G332.76 as part of the MALT90 survey (Foster et al. 2013). The peak brightness of the 13CS line was 0.3K, which, when scaling to our resolution, our higher energy transition, and higher abundance isotopologue (12CS), should correspond to 1.68 Jy/beam. This will be easily detected at the sensitivity required to detect the continuum.
Spatial resolution: We require at least two beams across each of the HII regions we are proposing to observe with ALMA. Previous 5GHz observations of these sources show that the HII regions themselves all have radii of at least 0.6” (the smallest being G337.63-00.08), and we will have two beams across it.
Spectral resolution: in order to quantify the dynamics of lines that are a few km/s wide, we require a spectral resolution of approximately 0.3 km/s, which is achievable using a resolution of 244 kHz.
Correlator setup: To understand the dynamics of the ionised gas, we require a radio recombination line (H29a). Key molecular species that can be observed simultaneously are SO_2 and CS. Additionally, to accurately determine the temperature of the warm molecular gas (key for determining the excitation of the molecular gas), we will observe an entire K-ladder of CH3CN. This requires a larger bandwidth than possible with a single Baseband, and so we have taken half of the channels from the other baseband in the same sideband to observe the rest of the K-ladder.
Imaging: With 8 min on source, our uv coverage will be sufficient for imaging.
There are no extraordinary constraints on the calibration, bandpass accuracy or for scheduling. We do however, have an above average data rate.
This high data rate is required because of the spectral lines we need to observe to obtain our scientific result. We require (more than) an entire baseband to observe the full K-ladder of CH3CN. With CS we trace the dynamics of the dense gas, and with SO2, we trace the warm gas. With two SO2 transitions (with very different energy levels) we can constrain the excitation of the warm gas as an independent check on the temperature estimate from the CH3CN. The H29a is required to understand the dynamics of the ionised gas, and thus key to our science.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
At the birth of a massive protostar, newly formed HII region expands into the surrounding medium. For the most part, our understanding of how and why are rooted in the Stromgren models, with only a few numerical simulations moving beyond this (e.g. Keto 2002, Peters et al. 2010).
In order to understand the dynamics, feedback and disruption of molecular clouds caused by massive stars shortly after they form HII regions, requires high-resolution sub-mm observations. From these observations, we can determine how the HII regions expand, leading towards answering why.
Here we propose Band 6 observations at 0.4'' of 9 small HII regions. We will use H29a to trace the dynamics of the ionised gas and three molecular species to trace the warm and dense gas around the HII regions. Through high sensitivity observations at the same resolution in both gas populations (ionised and molecular), we can understand the interaction between the HII region and its surrounding material as the ionisation front expands into it.

Center of Radio Astronomy and Astrophysics , Mexico, National Autonomous University of

Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek, University of Amsterdam
